questionList.questionText:
A 5-month-old girl is brought to the clinic for a weight check.  The patient has been evaluated several times for poor weight gain.  She takes 5-6 ounces of standard formula every 4 hours.  Increasing the caloric density of the formula has not improved her growth.  The patient has no diarrhea but frequently spits up after feeding.  She was born full term without complications.  Birth weight was 3.6 kg (8 lb; 50th percentile).  Current weight is <5th percentile; length and head circumference have been tracking along the 25th percentile.  The patient appears thin, but the remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Newborn screening results were normal.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Serum chemistry
Sodium140 mEq/L
Potassium3 mEq/L
Chloride119 mEq/L
Bicarbonate 11 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen10 mg/dL
Creatinine0.6 mg/dL
Urinalysis
pH7.8
Proteinnone
Glucosenegative
Ketonesnegative

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's failure to thrive?
questionList.explanationText:
Metabolic acidosis

Type

Normal anion gap

Elevated anion gap

Mechanism

  • Loss of bicarbonate
  • Accumulation of unmeasured acidic compounds

Common
causes

  • Severe diarrhea
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Excessive saline infusion
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Renal failure (uremia)
  • Methanol, ethylene glycol
  • Salicylate toxicity

This infant has low serum bicarbonate (HCO3−) and a normal anion gap of 10, laboratory findings consistent with a nonanion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA).  NAGMA typically results from renal or gastrointestinal net loss of HCO3−, leading to a relative increase in hydrogen ion (H+), along with an increase in serum chloride (Cl-) to maintain electronegative balance, as seen here.  In this child with poor growth and without diarrhea, renal tubular acidosis (RTA) should be suspected.

RTA is caused by an inherited or acquired defect in the ability of the renal tubules to reabsorb HCO3− (type 2 RTA) or excrete H+ (eg, type 1 RTA).  Infants often have growth failure due to chronic acidosis, and the specific laboratory abnormalities depend on the RTA subtype.

In this patient, alkalotic urine (pH >5.5) is consistent with type 1 RTA, in which the distal convoluted tubule fails to secrete H+ into the urine.  Because HCO3− cannot be generated and reabsorbed, acidosis occurs.  Conversely, defective HCO3− resorption in the proximal convoluted tubule leads to type 2 RTA, or Fanconi syndrome, which is characterized by generalized proximal tubular dysfunction and loss of other substances (eg, glucosuria; not seen in this patient).  Urine pH is typically <5.5 because serum HCO3− is so depleted that little remains to be secreted into the urine.  Hypokalemia is often seen in both conditions.

(Choice A)  Cystic fibrosis can present with failure to thrive and NAGMA but would be associated with malabsorption and chronic diarrhea; frequent sinopulmonary infections also contribute to poor growth.  This diagnosis is unlikely given the lack of gastrointestinal and pulmonary symptoms in this patient.

(Choice B)  Gastroesophageal reflux is common in infants and can cause failure to thrive due to feeding refusal (not seen in this patient) if severe.  Moreover, a nonanion gap acidosis is not expected.

(Choice C)  Inadequate caloric intake causes poor growth but not NAGMA in a well-hydrated child without diarrhea; alkalinized urine would also not be seen.  Moreover, this infant is feeding a sufficient volume for age (around 30-32 ounces a day).  Starvation is associated with a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (starvation ketoacidosis) rather than a NAGMA.

(Choice D)  Lactic acidosis, which is usually associated with poor tissue perfusion, causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Educational objective:
Renal tubular acidosis should be considered in infants with a nonanion gap metabolic acidosis, particularly in the setting of growth failure and absence of gastrointestinal bicarbonate loss (eg, diarrhea).  Pathogenesis involves a defect in either hydrogen excretion or bicarbonate resorption in the kidney.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Renal tubular acidosis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Renal Tubular Acidosis
Clinical profile and outcome of renal tubular disorders in children: a single center experience.

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office for postoperative follow-up.  Two weeks ago, the patient underwent transsphenoidal resection of a prolactinoma without complications.  The prolactin level normalized after the procedure, and the serum cortisol level at hospital discharge was normal.  The patient felt well until 3 days ago when she began experiencing nausea, malaise, and intermittent dizziness.  She has not had vomiting, diarrhea, fever, chills, or headaches.  Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.  Temperature is 36.9 C (98.4 F), blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 14/min.  The patient is alert and oriented.  There is no abnormal nasal drainage.  Cardiopulmonary examination is normal.  Cranial nerve examination, including assessment of visual acuity and extraocular movements along with funduscopy, is normal.  Motor strength, sensation, and deep tendon reflexes are normal.  Morning serum cortisol obtained prior to the office visit is 18 μg/dL (normal: 5-23).  Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has developed nonspecific symptoms (eg, nausea, malaise, dizziness) 2 weeks after undergoing resection of a prolactinoma.  The postoperative period of pituitary surgery can be complicated by disrupted salt and water balance from either one or both of the following:

  • Arginine vasopressin deficiency (AVP-D) (formerly central diabetes insipidus), characterized by polyuria due to water diuresis with normal to slightly elevated serum sodium.  The deficiency results from dysfunction of AVP-producing neurons (eg, from pituitary stalk manipulation) and occurs during the first few days after the procedure (usually resolving within a week).

  • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), characterized by normal/low urine output due to renal water retention with hyponatremia.  SIADH is the result of uncontrolled release of preformed AVP from degenerating neurons and arises several days after the procedure (lasting up to a few weeks).

Postoperative management includes measurement of serum electrolytes for the first few days after the procedure, to evaluate for both AVP-D and SIADH, and for several weeks afterward, to evaluate for SIADH.  Immediate postoperative evaluation for secondary adrenal insufficiency (AI), which can cause nonspecific symptoms and is characterized by low ACTH, is also recommended.  This patient has had several normal morning cortisol levels (including prior to the visit), making AI unlikely; she is also outside the window for postsurgical adrenal AI.  Therefore, further adrenal evaluation is not indicated (Choice C).

(Choice A)  CT scan of the head is particularly helpful for excluding intracranial hemorrhage, which is a very rare complication of transsphenoidal surgery.  However, hemorrhage is unlikely in this patient who is alert and oriented without headaches or focal neurologic deficits.  MRI of the brain is used in the postoperative period to assess for residual disease.

(Choice B)  Lumbar puncture is used to diagnose meningitis, which is a rare complication of pituitary surgery and is typically accompanied by cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea.  However, the absence of fever, headache, and rhinorrhea—in addition to the protracted time course—makes meningitis unlikely in this patient.

(Choice E)  Postoperative development of thyroid hormone deficiency (ie, secondary hypothyroidism) is rare and unlikely in this patient with normal vital signs and reflexes.  Moreover, TSH is unreliable in secondary hypothyroidism (unlike in primary hypothyroidism) because it can be low, normal, or high (free T4 levels are checked instead).

Educational objective:
Pituitary surgery can be complicated by postoperative arginine vasopressin deficiency (formerly central diabetes insipidus) and/or syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion.  Serum electrolytes should be measured for several weeks after the procedure.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Hyponatremia

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Disorders of salt and water balance after pituitary surgery.

questionList.questionText:
A 58-year-old woman comes to the office due to increasing fatigue and muscle cramps over the past 2 months.  She has a 5-year history of Sjögren syndrome and reports dryness of her eyes and mouth but no other symptoms.  Blood pressure is 130/74 mm Hg, and pulse is 86/min.  Physical examination shows enlarged parotid glands and dry oral mucosa.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Serum chemistry
Sodium139 mEq/L
Potassium3.1 mEq/L
Chloride116 mEq/L
Bicarbonate 13 mEq/L
Creatinine1.1 mg/dL
Arterial blood gases
pH7.32
PaO2100 mm Hg
PaCO226 mm Hg
Urine pH6.8

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acid-base imbalance?
questionList.explanationText:
Metabolic acidosis

Normal anion gap

Elevated anion gap

Mechanism

  • Loss of bicarbonate
  • Accumulation of unmeasured acidic compounds

Etiologies

  • Severe diarrhea
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Excess saline infusion
  • Intestinal or pancreatic fistula
  • CAI & MRA diuretics
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Kidney failure (uremia)
  • Methanol, ethylene glycol
  • Salicylate toxicity

CAI = carbonic anhydrase inhibitor; MRA = mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist.

This patient has primary metabolic acidosis, evidenced by pH <7.35 and serum bicarbonate (HCO3−) <24 mEq/L.  The normal anion gap of 10 mEq/L is consistent with nonanion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA), which results from loss of HCO3−.  This patient's NAGMA is likely due to type 1 renal tubular acidosis (RTA), a common complication of Sjögren syndrome.

There are 3 major types of RTA, all of which cause NAGMA due to a net loss of HCO3−.

  • Type 1 (distal) RTA results from impaired H+ excretion by alpha-intercalated cells in the distal tubule.  Hypokalemia is typically present due to reduced K+ reabsorption, and urine pH >5.5 is expected due to markedly impaired capacity to acidify the urine.

  • Type 2 (proximal) RTA results from impaired HCO3− reabsorption in the proximal tubule, and hypokalemia is usually present.  Because distal tubular H+ excretion is able to somewhat compensate for the impaired proximal HCO3− reabsorption, urine pH is variable and often <5.5.

  • Type 4 RTA results from reduced aldosterone activity, leading to impaired H+ and K+ excretion in the collecting duct.  In contrast to type 1 and type 2 RTA, hyperkalemia is typical.  The urine pH is usually <5.5.

(Choice A)  Impaired respiratory muscle function causes hypoventilation and primary respiratory acidosis, evidenced by pH <7.35 but elevated PaCO2 (>40 mm Hg).  This patient's low PaCO2 represents compensatory respiratory alkalosis for primary metabolic acidosis.

(Choices C and F)  Increased gastrointestinal HCO3− loss (eg, severe diarrhea) is a common cause of NAGMA.  Intracellular shift of HCO3− occurs with infusion of excess sodium chloride and leads to NAGMA.  These and most other etiologies of acidosis occur with intact distal tubular H+ excretion; therefore, low urine pH (<5.5) is expected as the kidneys can appropriately acidify the urine and excrete excess acid.  This patient's high urine pH in the setting of metabolic acidosis suggests a defect in renal acid handling.

(Choices D and E)  Anion gap metabolic acidosis (AGMA) results from the accumulation of unmeasured acidic compounds that increase the anion gap.  Increased ketoacid production is responsible for AGMA in severe insulin deficiency (ie, diabetic ketoacidosis), and increased lactic acid production causes AGMA during periods of poor organ and tissue perfusion (eg, sepsis).

Educational objective:
Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) involves a net loss of HCO3− and is a common cause of nonanion gap metabolic acidosis.  Type 1 RTA results from impaired H+ excretion in the distal tubule and can be recognized by inappropriately high urine pH (>5.5) in the setting of acidosis.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Renal tubular acidosis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Hyperchloremic acidosis.

questionList.questionText:
A 5-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with lethargy and tachypnea.  The boy was healthy before developing fever and diarrhea 4 days ago.  He has been taking some formula but has had 2-3 episodes of diarrhea with each bottle.  The patient has lost 3 lb (1.4 kg) since his routine check-up 2 weeks ago.  He has had a single wet diaper in the past day.  Temperature is 39.1 C (102.5 F), blood pressure is 70/45 mm Hg, pulse is 200/min, and respirations are 42/min.  He is lethargic with decreased tone and decreased deep tendon reflexes.  Mucous membranes are dry.  Cardiopulmonary examination reveals tachycardia and tachypnea.  Abdominal examination is unremarkable.  Capillary refill is 4 seconds.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Sodium165 mEq/L
Potassium4.5 mEq/L
Chloride110 mEq/L
Bicarbonate9 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)33 mg/dL
Creatinine0.8 mg/dL
Calcium10.0 mg/dL
Blood glucose98 mg/dL

Which of the following fluids should be used as a bolus in the resuscitation of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has severe dehydration and symptomatic hypovolemic hypernatremia, which can develop secondary to renal losses (eg, diuretic use, glycosuria) or extrarenal losses (eg, gastroenteritis, excessive sweating).  Water loss is relatively increased compared to sodium and potassium loss, thereby increasing the serum sodium concentration in these patients.  Infants are particularly at risk for developing hypernatremia with a gastrointestinal illness due to greater insensible losses (ie, increased body surface area) and the inability to communicate thirst.  Signs of hypernatremia can include irritability, muscle weakness, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and seizures in severe cases.

Hypovolemia can result in severe dehydration (eg, dry mucous membranes, tachycardia, delayed capillary refill, hypotension), which is concerning because it can progress to shock and cardiovascular compromise.  Therefore, initial treatment of symptomatic hypovolemic hypernatremia (eg, with severe dehydration) is to restore circulatory volume and tissue perfusion by emergency fluid resuscitation.

  • As with adults, the total fluid deficit is a combination of free water deficit and isotonic fluid losses.

  • However, hypotonic solutions should not be used in the emergency fluid rescucitation of pediatric patients with hypovolemic hypernatremia due to the risk of neurologic complications with rapid overcorrection.

In such cases, resuscitation should begin with an isotonic (compared to normal serum sodium) solution such as 0.9% normal saline.  Hypernatremia should then be corrected gradually (<0.5 mEq/L/hr) to prevent neurologic complications (eg, cerebral edema) from excessive movement of water into brain cells.

(Choices A and D)  Half normal (0.45%) saline and 5% dextrose in water are hypotonic solutions that may be used to correct hypernatremia in patients without marked volume depletion or after restoration of intravascular volume in dehydrated patients.  Hypotonic solutions are not used for initial fluid resuscitation in a pediatric patient with signs of severe dehydration because rapid infusion lowers sodium too quickly.

(Choice C)  Colloid solutions (eg, 5% albumin) may be considered in patients with low oncotic pressure (eg, nephrotic syndrome) but are expensive and not proven to be more effective than crystalloids at fluid resuscitation.

(Choice E)  10% dextrose in water is a hypertonic solution that may be used for the treatment of hypoglycemia, not seen here.

(Choice F)  Intravenous sodium bicarbonate may be considered for severe metabolic acidosis but is not indicated for fluid resuscitation.  In addition, this solution is hypertonic and would worsen hypernatremia.

Educational objective:
Initial treatment of pediatric patients who have hypovolemic hypernatremia with signs of dehydration (eg, dry mucous membranes, tachycardia) is to restore circulatory volume and tissue perfusion by emergency fluid resuscitation with an isotonic solution (eg, 0.9% normal saline).
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Hypernatremia

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Dehydration: isonatremic, hyponatremic, and hypernatremic recognition and management.

questionList.questionText:
A 67-year-old man with mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is brought to the emergency department by his daughter with the chief complaint of seizure.  The patient has had episodes of confusion and lethargy over the past week.  He complains of some exertional shortness of breath and nonproductive cough.  His daughter believes that he is losing weight and has decreased appetite.  His temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 134/88 mm Hg, and pulse is 104/min and irregular.  The mucous membranes are moist and there is no peripheral edema.  Neurologic examination is unremarkable.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hematocrit34%
Serum chemistry
    Sodium117 mEq/L
    Potassium5.4 mEq/L
    Bicarbonate22 mEq/L
    Creatinine1.3 mg/dL

Rapid correction of this patient's metabolic abnormalities puts him at highest risk of which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient presents with a provoked seizure in the setting of severe hyponatremia.  This is considered a medical emergency and requires prompt correction of the serum sodium concentration with 3% saline solution.  However, correction of the serum sodium should not exceed 0.5 mEq/L/hr to avoid causing irreversible brain damage from osmotic demyelination or central pontine myelinolysis.  Rapid correction of serum sodium in the setting of hyponatremia results in excess water being moved by osmosis from the intracellular compartment (neurons and glia) into the extracellular compartment.  This in turn leads to disruption of cellular metabolic activity and subsequent cell damage.  The opposite is true when rapidly correcting a patient with hypernatremia, when cerebral edema can occur (Choice A).

This patient's hyponatremia could be from lung cancer-associated syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone given his euvolemic status, recent weight loss, and smoking history.

(Choice B)  This patient has an irregular heart rhythm, which may be secondary to atrial fibrillation, and therefore is at increased risk of an embolic stroke.  However, rapid correction of his hyponatremia will not contribute to that risk.

(Choice C)  Rapid correction of hyponatremia results in increased water movement out of brain tissue and so would not contribute to the formation of hydrocephalus.  Hydrocephalus can be either obstructive (noncommunicating) or nonobstructive (communicating), resulting from excess cerebrospinal fluid production or impaired cerebrospinal fluid absorption.

(Choice E)  Electrolyte abnormalities can result in cardiac arrhythmias.  However, rapid correction of hyponatremia is more likely to result in osmotic demyelination in the central nervous system than to cause a ventricular arrhythmia.

Educational objective:
Acute, symptomatic hyponatremia (impaired mental status/seizures) is a medical emergency.  It requires a prompt increase in the serum sodium concentration with 3% or hypertonic saline at a rate of no more than 0.5 mEq/L/hr to avoid causing central nervous system osmotic demyelination syndrome.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Central pontine myelinolysis

questionList.questionText:
A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to shortness of breath, headache, and fatigue.  He has a history of hypertension, lives alone, and does not regularly take his medications.  The patient drinks 1 or 2 glasses of wine daily but does not smoke.  Blood pressure is 184/128 mm Hg and pulse is 96/min.  Oxygen saturation is 90% by pulse oximetry on room air.  The patient has early papilledema on funduscopic examination.  Pulmonary examination shows bibasilar coarse crackles.  Cardiac examination demonstrates a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border.  There is trace pedal edema.  Chest x-ray reveals mild pulmonary edema.  ECG is unchanged from prior tracings.  Laboratory studies are normal except for a serum creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL.  The patient is given oxygen and furosemide and is prescribed a nitroprusside drip.  After 36 hours, blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and he is no longer dyspneic; however, he is confused and disoriented and has diffuse hyperreflexia.  There are no other focal neurologic findings.  Repeat laboratory results are as follows:

Sodium140 mEq/L
Potassium4.4 mEq/L
Chloride100 mEq/L
Bicarbonate14 mEq/L
Creatinine2.5 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Cyanide poisoning

Common etiologies

  • Structure fires (eg, combustion of plastics)
  • Occupational exposure (eg, mining)
  • Cyanide-containing medications (eg, sodium nitroprusside)

Pathophysiology

  • Inhibits oxidative phosphorylation & forces anaerobic metabolism
  • Rapidly lethal if untreated

Clinical features

  • Hypertension, tachycardia, tachypnea → circulatory collapse, death
  • Headache, confusion, anxiety → seizures, coma
  • Cherry-red skin
  • Elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis with ↑ lactic acid

Management

  • Decontamination
  • Supportive care (eg, 100% oxygen, intravenous fluids, vasopressors)
  • Empiric treatment with hydroxocobalamin ± sodium thiosulfate*

*Sodium nitrite + sodium thiosulfate is an alternate treatment but is contraindicated in carbon monoxide poisoning.

This patient with hypertensive emergency was treated with sodium nitroprusside, a potent arterial and venous vasodilator.  After 36 hours, he developed acute neurologic symptoms (eg, confusion, hyperreflexia) and metabolic acidosis, a presentation most concerning for cyanide toxicity.  Sodium nitroprusside contains 5 cyanide groups and undergoes rapid conversion to cyanide.  Cyanide is eventually converted to thiocyanate, which is eliminated by the kidneys; however, especially in patients with renal impairment, prolonged sodium nitroprusside infusion (eg, >24 hr) can lead to cyanide toxicity.

Cyanide inhibits mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation.  This forces cells to switch to anaerobic metabolism and leads to cellular hypoxia, lactic acid formation, and metabolic acidosis (eg, bicarbonate: 14 mEq/L) with an elevated anion gap.  Neurologic symptoms (eg, headache, confusion) are common due to cerebral cellular hypoxia.  Hyperreflexia is caused by thiocyanate accumulation.  Other possible manifestations include cardiovascular and respiratory instability, gastrointestinal symptoms (eg, vomiting), and reddish skin.

In addition to medication use, other etiologies of cyanide toxicity include combustion of carbon- and nitrogen-containing compounds (eg, wool, silk) and industrial exposure (eg, metal extraction in mining).

(Choice A)  Severe alcohol withdrawal (eg, delirium tremens) can cause confusion and disorientation, but tachycardia is also typically present.  In addition, it is more common in patients with heavy alcohol use who suddenly stop drinking and less likely in this patient with moderate alcohol use.

(Choice C)  In patients with chronic hypertension, cerebral vessels may not autoregulate, which can lead to global hypoperfusion and cerebral ischemia if blood pressure is lowered dramatically and rapidly.  However, this patient's blood pressure was appropriately decreased by approximately 25% over 36 hours, making this diagnosis unlikely.  In addition, elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis would not be expected.

(Choice D)  Lacunar infarcts are small strokes from occluded penetrating arteries deep in the brain.  They typically present with focal neurologic deficits (eg, pure sensory or motor deficits), which are not present in this patient, and do not typically cause metabolic acidosis.

(Choice E)  Uremic encephalopathy can present with altered mentation; however, it usually occurs in patients with advanced renal failure.  This patient's mild rise in creatinine from 2.0 to 2.5 mg/dL is unlikely to cause uremic encephalopathy.

Educational objective:
Sodium nitroprusside infusion can result in cyanide toxicity, particularly in patients with renal insufficiency.  Clinical findings consistent with cyanide poisoning include metabolic acidosis and neurologic changes (eg, headache, confusion).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Cyanide poisoning

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Sodium nitroprusside in 2014: A clinical concepts review.

questionList.questionText:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother due to polyuria and dizziness for the past several weeks.  The patient has had no dysuria, suprapubic pain, vomiting, or changes in bowel movements.  Medical history is unremarkable.  Blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg and pulse is 60/min.  No orthostatic changes are present.  The patient is alert and oriented and appears well nourished.  Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  Cranial nerves are intact.  Motor and sensory examinations are normal.  Deep tendon reflexes are normal.  Urine output exceeds 3 L/day.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Sodium130 mEq/L
Potassium3.7 mEq/L
Bicarbonate24 mEq/L
Calcium8.7 mg/dL
Creatinine0.6 mg/dL
Glucose98 mg/dL
Serum osmolality265 mOsm/kg (normal: 275-295)
Urine osmolality94 mOsm/kg
Urinalysis
Specific gravity1.003
Proteinnone
Leukocyte esterasenegative

Which of the following additional tests is most appropriate for making the diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
ADH/AVP-related causes of polyuria & polydipsia

Primary polydipsia

AVP deficiency
(central DI)

AVP resistance
(nephrogenic DI)

Defect

  • ↑ Water intake
  • ↓ ADH release from pituitary gland
  • Renal ADH resistance (normal or ↑ ADH)

Etiology

  • Antipsychotic use
  • Anxiety, psychiatric condition
  • Idiopathic
  • Trauma
  • Pituitary surgery
  • Ischemic encephalopathy
  • Long-term lithium use
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hereditary (AVPR2 mutation)

Clinical features

  • Low serum Na
  • High-normal or elevated serum Na*
  • Normal or mildly elevated serum Na*

*Na is elevated if thirst mechanism is impaired (eg, hypothalamic involvement).

ADH = antidiuretic hormone; AVP = arginine vasopressin; DI = diabetes insipidus.

This adolescent patient has polyuria (urine output >3 L/day), which can be due to the following causes:

  • Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) (arginine vasopressin [AVP]) deficiency or resistance
  • Solute diuresis (eg, glucosuria)
  • Primary polydipsia (formerly psychogenic polydipsia)

AVP deficiency and resistance (formerly diabetes insipidus) lead to urinary wasting of water and are accompanied by either normal or elevated serum sodium; this patient's hyponatremia excludes AVP deficiency and resistance.  Hyponatremia with a low serum osmolality indicates hypotonic hyponatremia.  Hypotonic hyponatremia with a low urine osmolality (<100 mOsm/kg), as in this patient, indicates primary polydipsia, which occurs when water intake exceeds the hypothalamic osmotic threshold for thirst.  This can lead to excessive water content in the blood (eg, hyponatremia) with resultant urinary water excretion (ie, dilute urine with a specific gravity <1.010).  Primary polydipsia typically affects patients with psychiatric conditions (eg, schizophrenia, obsessive-compulsive disorder) and those who take antipsychotic medications (eg, due to increased thirst).

Primary polydipsia can be diagnosed without additional testing in patients (like this one) with both polyuria and hyponatremia.  However, patients with polyuria and normal serum sodium should undergo water deprivation testing to differentiate between primary polydipsia (polyuria will resolve as urine osmolality increases) and AVP deficiency or resistance (polyuria will persist as urine osmolality remains low).  Treatment consists of decreasing water intake (ie, "drink to thirst" only).

(Choice A)  Hemoglobin A1c testing is used to help diagnose diabetes mellitus, which can cause hyperglycemia with a resultant solute diuresis from glucosuria.  However, hypertonic hyponatremia (ie, high serum osmolality) and a high urine specific gravity would be expected.

(Choice C)  Serum TSH and cortisol measurement can help diagnose hypothyroidism and adrenal insufficiency, respectively.  These conditions can also cause hypotonic hyponatremia by increasing ADH.  However, they are unlikely in the setting of polyuria and low urine osmolality; urine volume would be low/normal and urine osmolality would be high because ADH increases water reabsorption.

(Choice D)  A urine toxicology screen can confirm suspected MDMA (ecstasy) intoxication, which can acutely cause hyponatremia from syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion.  However, urine osmolality would be high (eg, exceeding serum osmolality), and polyuria would not be expected.  In addition, this patient lacks evidence of MDMA intoxication (eg, hypertension, tachycardia, agitation).

Educational objective:
In patients with polyuria, the presence of both hypotonic hyponatremia and low urine osmolality (<100 mOsm/kg) is diagnostic of primary polydipsia (without the need for a water deprivation test).  Primary polydipsia develops when water intake exceeds the hypothalamic osmotic threshold for thirst.  Treatment consists of decreasing water intake.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Primary polydipsia

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Primary polydipsia: update.

questionList.questionText: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for lethargy and drowsiness.  The patient's husband reports that over the past 2 days she has been sleeping more and has had trouble walking.  This morning, she managed to get into the bathtub but was too weak to get out.  Medical history is significant for hypertension, chronic kidney disease, chronic low back pain, and frequent constipation.  She takes amlodipine daily and acetaminophen/hydrocodone and magnesium citrate as needed.  Temperature is 36.1 C (97 F), blood pressure is 90/68 mm Hg, pulse is 52/min, and respirations are 10/min.  Pulse oximetry shows 92% on room air.  The patient is lethargic and somnolent.  The pupils are equal and reactive to light.  Auscultation of the heart and lungs is normal.  The abdomen is soft and nondistended.  Strength in the upper and lower extremities is 2/5, and deep tendon reflexes are absent.  The patient's condition does not change with naloxone administration.  Serum creatinine is at her baseline value of 2.3 mg/dL.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Magnesium toxicity

Causes

  • Renal impairment (ie, decreased Mg excretion)
  • Increased Mg intake (eg, IV Mg sulfate, Mg-based laxatives/enemas)

Clinical features

  • Neuromuscular: ↓ reflexes, weakness, paralysis, respiratory failure
  • Cardiovascular: hypotension, bradycardia, conduction defects
  • Electrolyte: hypocalcemia

Management

  • Discontinue Mg-containing medications
  • IV fluids ± loop diuretics
  • IV calcium for neuromuscular & cardiac symptoms
  • Hemodialysis in severe renal impairment

IV = intravenous; Mg = magnesium.

This patient most likely has magnesium toxicity, evidenced by lethargy, weakness, loss of deep tendon reflexes, hypotension, bradycardia, and respiratory depression.  In this case, toxicity is likely due to increased ingestion of magnesium citrate, a magnesium-containing laxative.  Patients, such as this one, with impaired renal function are at greater risk of toxicity because of the kidney's typical role in maintaining normal plasma magnesium levels.  Common clinical manifestations of magnesium toxicity include the following:

  • Neuromuscular effects:  Hypermagnesemia decreases impulse transmission across the neuromuscular junction, initially resulting in decreased deep tendon reflexes and muscle weakness.  As serum magnesium levels rise, this can progress to absent reflexes, complete paralysis, respiratory depression, and respiratory arrest.

  • Cardiovascular effects:  Magnesium can act as a channel blocker at both cardiac calcium and potassium channels.  Increased plasma magnesium levels can cause conduction defects (eg, PR prolongation, QT prolongation), bradycardia, and hypotension.

  • Electrolyte abnormalities:  Hypermagnesemia can suppress release of parathyroid hormone, leading to hypocalcemia, which can worsen cardiovascular effects (eg, hypotension, QT prolongation).

Significant neuromuscular or cardiovascular symptoms are treated with intravenous calcium, which antagonizes the effects of magnesium.  In addition, magnesium excretion is promoted via intravenous fluids and loop diuretics for patients with normal renal function or via hemodialysis for patients with severely impaired renal function.

(Choice A)  Although cerebellar infarction due to occlusion of a posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) branch can cause difficulty walking (due to gait incoordination), bradycardia and hypotension are not typically present.  In addition, vertigo and unilateral limb ataxia are commonly present.

(Choice B)  Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) classically presents with weakness (usually symmetrical and ascending), absent reflexes, and dysautonomia (eg, hypotension, bradycardia).  However, patients with GBS typically have a normal mental status (vs lethargy and somnolence).

(Choice D)  Patients with an opioid overdose can have lethargy, somnolence, and respiratory depression.  However, reflexes are typically normal (vs absent), pupils are miotic (vs normal), and symptoms are typically immediately reversed with naloxone (vs no change).

(Choice E)  Uremic polyneuropathy, a slowly progressive demyelinating polyneuropathy in patients with chronic kidney disease, can cause loss of deep tendon reflexes and muscle weakness.  However, it has a gradual (vs sudden) onset, and bradycardia, respiratory depression, and hypotension are not typically present.

Educational objective:
Magnesium toxicity can occur from increased intake of magnesium-containing compounds, especially in patients with impaired renal function.  Toxicity classically causes neuromuscular effects (eg, decreased deep tendon reflexes, weakness, respiratory depression) and cardiovascular effects (eg, bradycardia, hypotension).

questionList.questionText:
A 72-year-old man is evaluated in the hospital for new-onset polyuria.  The patient was admitted 5 days ago due to subdural hematoma after a fall.  He underwent urgent craniotomy and hematoma evacuation but has had poor neurologic recovery.  The patient remains intubated on a mechanical ventilator and is receiving enteral feeding via an orogastric tube.  Daily urine output has been 3,000-4,000 mL over the past 2 days.  Medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus; there is no history of kidney disease.  Current medications are amlodipine, insulin, dexmedetomidine, and levetiracetam.  Blood pressure is 122/68 mm Hg and pulse is 70/min.  Jugular venous pressure is normal.  The lungs are clear to auscultation.  There is no extremity edema.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Sodium130 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen20 mg/dL
Creatinine0.8 mg/dL
Calcium9.2 mg/dL
Glucose348 mg/dL
Serum osmolality286 mOsm/kg
Urine osmolality720 mOsm/kg

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's polyuria?
questionList.explanationText:
This critically ill patient has developed polyuria (urine output >3 L/day) following a craniotomy.  Polyuria can be classified as follows:

  • Water diuresis due to urinary loss of solute-free water, either from primary polydipsia or arginine vasopressin (AVP) deficiency/resistance

  • Solute diuresis due to urinary excretion of an osmotically active substance (eg, glucose, mannitol) that draws water into the urine

Water and solute diuresis can be differentiated by measuring urine osmolality.  Low urine osmolality (<300 mOsm/kg) indicates water diuresis (ie, dilute urine).  High urine osmolality (>600 mOsm/kg, as in this patient) indicates solute diuresis (ie, concentrated urine).  Equivocal urine osmolality (300-600 mOsm/kg) warrants further evaluation.

Solute diuresis is usually caused by urinary excretion of nonelectrolyte substances (eg, glucose, mannitol, urea), although diuresis from electrolyte loss can also occur (eg, sodium loss after large-volume saline administration).  This patient's hyperglycemia (glucose 348 mg/dL) has led to osmotic pulling of water out of cells (hyponatremia) and into the urine (polyuria, glucosuria).  Hyperglycemia-induced osmotic diuresis can cause variable serum osmolality and sodium.  In this patient, the combination of hyperglycemia (increases osmolality) and hyponatremia (decreases osmolality) explains his normal serum osmolality.

In patients with brain injury (eg, trauma, procedure) who develop polyuria and hyponatremia, cerebral salt wasting (CSW) syndrome (eg, urinary sodium losses due to brain natriuretic peptide secretion) should be considered.  However, CSW syndrome is characterized by low serum osmolality and typically prominent hypovolemia (eg, hypotension), unlike this patient.

(Choices A and B)  AVP deficiency and resistance (formerly central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus) cause water diuresis and would result in low urine osmolality.  Moreover, these conditions result in either elevated or high-normal serum sodium.

(Choice C)  Excessive enteral feeding of free water (like primary polydipsia) can cause water overload with ensuing water diuresis (ie, low urine osmolality), which is absent in this patient.

(Choice E)  Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion also causes hyponatremia with a high urine osmolality, but polyuria is not a feature.  High urine osmolality is due to urinary solutes becoming more concentrated as water is pulled out of the urine by antidiuretic hormone (ie, no polyuria).  In contrast, high urine osmolality in solute diuresis is due to a high solute concentration pulling water into the urine (ie, polyuria).

Educational objective:
Polyuria (urine output >3 L/day) can be due to water diuresis (urine osmolality <300 mOsm/kg) or solute diuresis (>600 mOsm/kg).  A common cause of solute diuresis is glucosuria (eg, from hyperglycemia).

questionList.questionText:
An 18-year-old African American man comes to the office due to several months of excessive urination.  The patient voids every few hours during the day and wakes 2 or 3 times per night to urinate despite restricting his evening fluid intake.  He says that his urine appears clear and has no visible blood.  Medical history is significant for seasonal allergies, for which he frequently takes an antihistamine.  He takes no other medications and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  The patient is sexually active and does not use condoms.  He was adopted at a young age; records indicate that his birth mother had sickle cell disease and died from a stroke at age 32.  The patient is afebrile and normotensive.  Hematocrit is 41% and serum sodium is 138 mEq/L.  Urinalysis of a first-morning specimen reveals the following:

Specific gravity1.001(normal: 1.010-1.030)
pH6.6(normal: 4.5-8)
Proteinnone
Bloodnegative
Glucosenegative
Ketonesnegative
Leukocyte esterasenegative
Nitritesnegative

This patient's polyuria is most likely caused by which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
Sickle cell trait

Clinical features

  • Usually asymptomatic
  • No change in overall life expectancy

Laboratory findings

  • Normal hemoglobin, reticulocyte count, RBC indices & morphology
  • Hemoglobin electrophoresis: Hb A > Hb S

Complications

  • Hematuria/papillary necrosis, hyposthenuria
  • Splenic infarction (especially at higher altitudes), venous thromboembolism, priapism
  • Exertional rhabdomyolysis

Hb A = hemoglobin A; Hb S = hemoglobin S; RBC = red blood cell.

This patient has a low urine specific gravity consistent with hyposthenuria, the inability of the kidneys to concentrate urine.  His family history is significant for early-onset stroke, which can be a severe complication of sickle cell disease (SCD) due to cerebrovascular occlusion from sickling; however, he has a normal hematocrit level and no other symptoms.  Therefore, sickle cell trait (SCT) is the most likely cause of this patient's hyposthenuria.

Hyposthenuria is common in patients with SCD and may also develop in those with SCT.  In response to hypoxic, hyperosmolar conditions of the renal medulla, red blood cells sickle in the vasa recta, impairing free water reabsorption and countercurrent exchange.  Patients typically have polyuria and nocturia despite fluid restriction.  Urine osmolality is low; however, normal serum sodium is maintained due to intact antidiuretic hormone (ADH).  Urinary diluting capacity is also intact as it is a function of the superficial loop of Henle, which is not supplied by the vasa recta.

Typically, mild hyposthenuria due to SCT requires no treatment.  In patients with SCD, red blood cell transfusions often improve urine-concentrating ability and provide relief of symptoms.

(Choice A)  Central diabetes insipidus causes polyuria and hyposthenuria due to insufficient ADH production.  However, thirst mechanism is impaired and serum sodium is elevated in patients with central diabetes insipidus.

(Choice B)  Chlamydia infection in men can cause dysuria and urethral discharge.  Impaired urine-concentrating ability is not associated with chlamydia infection, and urinalysis would likely be positive for leukocyte esterase.

(Choice D)  Antihistamines (eg, diphenhydramine) treat allergic rhinitis and can cause anticholinergic adverse effects such as dry mouth, tachycardia, and urinary retention, none of which is consistent with this patient's presentation.

(Choice E)  Primary (psychogenic) polydipsia causes hyposthenuria due to excessive water intake.  However, serum sodium is typically low, and this condition is unlikely in a patient restricting evening fluid intake.

(Choices F and G)  Diabetes mellitus is characterized by elevated serum glucose due to lack of insulin (type 1) or insulin resistance (type 2).  When serum glucose exceeds the capacity of kidney resorption, glucose draws water into the collecting system, causing polyuria and glucosuria.  Negative urine glucose makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Educational objective:
Hyposthenuria is the inability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and can occur in patients with sickle cell disease and sickle cell trait.  Patients have polyuria, low urine specific gravity, and normal serum sodium.

questionList.questionText:
A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to fever, chills, and confusion.  The patient was fishing in the ocean yesterday and cut his foot on a jagged rock while wading through shallow water.  He was unable to clean the wound right away, and overnight, it became increasingly red and painful.  The patient was awakened several times by fever and chills, and this morning, his wife found him disoriented.  Medical history includes hypertension.  Temperature is 38.8 C (101.8 F), blood pressure is 86/62 mm Hg, pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 24/min.  On physical examination, the patient is in moderate distress.  Heart sounds are rapid and regular with no murmurs.  The lungs are clear to auscultation.  Breathing is fast and shallow.  The right foot shows a laceration with purulent drainage and erythema spreading to the midshin.  The results of arterial blood gas testing on room air are as follows:

pH7.08
PaO286 mm Hg
PaCO242 mm Hg
Serum bicarbonate12 mEq/L

Which of the following best describes the acid-base status of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Mixed primary acid-base disorders

HCO3−

PaCO2

pH

Example

Metabolic acidosis +
respiratory acidosis

↓

↑

Very low

Sepsis (lactic acidosis)
with respiratory failure

Metabolic alkalosis +
respiratory alkalosis

↑

↓

Very high

Hyperemesis gravidarum &
hyperventilation of pregnancy

Metabolic acidosis +
respiratory alkalosis

↓

↓

Near normal

Salicylate toxicity

Metabolic alkalosis +
respiratory acidosis

↑

↑

Near normal

Overdiuresed heart failure
& underlying COPD

Metabolic acidosis +

metabolic alkalosis

↔

↔

Near normal

Diabetic ketoacidosis
with severe vomiting

COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

A mixed acid-base disorder involves ≥2 primary disturbances and may be suggested by either a very abnormal pH (eg, <7.2 or >7.6) or a near-normal pH despite significant abnormalities in serum bicarbonate (HCO3−) and PaCO2.  Acid-base status is best evaluated in a stepwise fashion:

  1. Evaluate the pH (normal: 7.4): This patient's low pH of 7.08 indicates acidemia.

  2. Identify the primary process: Analyze the metabolic component of acid-base balance, serum HCO3− (normal: 24 mEq/L), and the respiratory component, PaCO2 (normal: 40 mm Hg).  The parameter shifted in the direction that explains the change in pH represents the primary disturbance.  This patient's serum HCO3− is significantly low (shifted toward acidity), indicating metabolic acidosis.

  3. Determine the compensation: Primary metabolic disturbances are quickly compensated via adjustments in alveolar ventilation and CO2 removal.  The expected compensation for this patient's metabolic acidosis is respiratory alkalosis with a PaCO2 of approximately 26 mm Hg (estimated using Winters formula).  However, this patient's PaCO2 of 42 mm Hg is much higher than expected (inappropriate compensation) (Choice A), indicating respiratory acidosis as a second primary disturbance.

The clinical presentation should then be examined to ensure that all primary disturbances are explained.  This patient has sepsis due to lower extremity cellulitis (eg, fever, hemodynamic instability), which explains primary metabolic acidosis due to lactic acidosis.  The marked acidemia caused by severe sepsis creates high ventilatory demand that a patient may be unable to meet.  This patient's rapid, shallow breathing suggests respiratory muscle fatigue and hypoventilation, which constitutes respiratory failure and accounts for primary respiratory acidosis.  In addition to antibiotics and intravenous fluids for sepsis, such patients often require intubation and mechanical ventilation.

(Choice B)  Compensated respiratory acidosis is typical of chronic hypoventilation (eg, obesity hypoventilation syndrome).  Low pH, elevated PaCO2, and an appropriate compensatory increase in HCO3− are expected.

(Choice D)  Mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis could occur with sepsis due to pneumonia.  Consistent acid-based findings are near-normal pH (opposing processes), low HCO3−, and PaCO2 that is lower than the expected respiratory compensation.

(Choice E)  Mixed metabolic alkalosis and respiratory acidosis could occur with severe vomiting and opioid overdose.  Consistent findings are near-normal pH, elevated HCO3−, and higher-than-expected PaCO2.

Educational objective:
Mixed acid-base disorders involve ≥2 primary disturbances and can be recognized by inappropriate compensation for the initial primary disturbance.  Sepsis with respiratory failure is a common cause of mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Metabolic acidosis

answerChoiceList.choice: Mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis
Mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis
Mixed metabolic alkalosis and respiratory acidosis

questionList.questionText:
A 66-year-old man comes to the office for a routine visit.  He has no current complaints.  The patient has a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension.  His blood work from 2 months ago showed hyperkalemia, and lisinopril was discontinued at that time.  The patient's current medications include glipizide, furosemide, nifedipine, and aspirin.  His blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min.  Examination is unremarkable.  Repeat blood test results today are as follows:

Sodium136 mEq/L
Potassium5.8 mEq/L
Chloride108 mEq/L
Bicarbonate18 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen28 mg/dL
Creatinine1.4 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's electrolyte abnormalities?
questionList.explanationText:
Causes of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

  • Diarrhea
  • Fistulae (eg, pancreatic, ileocutaneous, etc.)
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Ureteral diversion (eg, ileal loop)
  • Iatrogenic

This patient has a metabolic acidosis (given his low serum bicarbonate of 18 mEq/L) with hyperkalemia.  He has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis with a serum anion gap of 10 mEq/L (anion gap = serum Na+ - [serum Cl- + serum HCO3-]; normal anion gap = 10-14 mEq/L).  He also has a mild degree of renal dysfunction consistent with chronic kidney disease.  When there is a gradual loss of nephrons, the remaining nephrons maintain the kidney's ability to excrete a daily acid load by producing more NH3 buffer that removes H+ as NH4+ in the urine.  As a result, metabolic acidosis in chronic kidney disease is rarely seen until there is advanced renal dysfunction (glomerular filtration rate <20 mL/min).  Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia that occur out of proportion to the renal dysfunction indicate a renal tubular disorder.

Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is a group of disorders characterized by non-anion gap metabolic acidosis in the presence of preserved kidney function.  The cortical collecting tubule is the site for H+ and K+ excretion, which is regulated by aldosterone.  Impaired function of the cortical collecting tubule due to aldosterone deficiency or resistance will cause retention of H+ and K+ and is termed hyperkalemic RTA (or type 4 RTA).  Hyperkalemic RTA is commonly seen in elderly patients who have poorly controlled diabetes with damage to the juxtaglomerular apparatus, which causes a state of hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism.  These patients have mild hyperkalemia (K+ 5.2-6.0 mEq/L) and mild acidosis (HCO3- 15-20 mEq/L) on a background of preserved or moderately diminished glomerular filtration rate (20-50 mL/min).  Hypertension may or may not be present and is usually due to the accompanying atherosclerosis.

(Choice A)  Loop diuretic use causes hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

(Choice B)  Although diarrhea most commonly causes metabolic acidosis, diarrhea from laxative abuse often causes severe hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.  The severe hypokalemia occurs due to potassium losses in the stool and increased aldosterone secretion due to volume depletion.  This leads to impaired chloride reabsorption and bicarbonate excretion, resulting in metabolic alkalosis.

(Choice C)  In pre-renal azotemia (renal hypoperfusion) the blood urea nitrogen/creatinine ratio is usually more than 20:1 due to increased urea absorption.  Renal hypoperfusion is due to either systemic hypovolemia or impaired cardiac output.  This patient has no symptoms or signs of volume depletion.

(Choice D)  In primary hyperaldosteronism, high aldosterone levels cause increased H+ and K+ excretion, leading to hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis (mnemonic: Aldosterone Saves Sodium and Pushes Potassium out).

(Choice E)  Renal artery stenosis causes secondary hyperaldosteronism due to low perfusion to the kidney.  Hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and hypertension are characteristic findings.

(Choice G)  Surreptitious vomiting causes a hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to loss of gastric HCl.  Hypokalemia may be seen due to increased aldosterone secretion caused by volume depletion.

Educational objective:
Type 4 renal tubular acidosis (hyperkalemic renal tubular acidosis) is characterized by non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, persistent hyperkalemia, and mild-to-moderate renal insufficiency.  It commonly occurs in patients with poorly controlled diabetes.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Renal tubular acidosis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Mechanisms in hyperkalemic renal tubular acidosis.

questionList.questionText:
A 58-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis from alcohol use is brought to the emergency department due to worsening lethargy and abdominal distension.  On examination, he is obtunded and has scleral icterus, asterixis, and tense ascites.  The patient is intubated to maintain airway patency.  The lungs are mechanically ventilated, and he is hospitalized for further management.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Admission4 days later
Arterial pH7.347.47
Serum bicarbonate19 mEq/L31 mEq/L
Serum sodium133 mEq/L135 mEq/L
Serum potassium4.6 mEq/L3.1 mEq/L
Serum chloride101 mEq/L92 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen34 mg/dL45 mg/dL
Serum creatinine1.7 mg/dL2.1 mg/dL

Which of the following best explains this patient's change in acid-base status?
questionList.explanationText:
Common causes of primary acid-base disturbance

Metabolic acidosis

Elevated anion gap

  • Poor tissue perfusion (ie, lactic acidosis)
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Kidney failure (ie, uremia)
  • Certain toxicities (eg, methanol, ethylene glycol)

Normal anion gap

  • Severe diarrhea
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Excess normal saline infusion

Metabolic alkalosis

  • Nasogastric suctioning or severe vomiting
  • Diuretic overuse
  • Primary hyperaldosteronism

Respiratory acidosis
(hypoventilation)

  • Central respiratory depression (eg, opioid overdose)
  • OHS, neuromuscular weakness
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

Respiratory alkalosis
(hyperventilation)

  • Acute V/Q mismatch (eg, PE, pneumonia)
  • Anxiety, inadequate pain control
  • High altitude, pregnancy

OHS = obesity hypoventilation syndrome; PE = pulmonary embolism; V/Q = ventilation/perfusion.

This patient has evidence of decompensated cirrhosis, including ascites, scleral icterus, and hepatic encephalopathy, for which he is intubated.  He now has alkalemia (pH >7.45), with laboratory studies (eg, elevated bicarbonate [HCO3−]) consistent with metabolic alkalosis.

Ascites, caused by portal hypertension, leads to sodium (Na+) and fluid retention.  Management includes loop diuretics (eg, furosemide), which promote urinary excretion of Na+, water, potassium (K+), and chloride (Cl−) (by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl− transporter).  This causes potent diuresis and electrolyte derangements (eg, hypokalemia, hypochloremia).

These electrolyte derangements also increase renal hydrogen (H+) excretion, which, along with diuretic-induced volume contraction, results in metabolic alkalosis.  Metabolic alkalosis is compensated for by hypoventilation, which causes PaCO2 to rise (secondary respiratory acidosis).

(Choice A)  Mechanical ventilation can lead to respiratory (vs metabolic) alkalosis if the respiratory rate and/or tidal volume on the ventilator is set too high (ie, hyperventilation).  However, unlike metabolic alkalosis, serum HCO3− is low because the kidneys compensate for decreased PaCO2 (the primary disturbance).

(Choice B)  Hepatic hydrothorax can develop as ascitic fluid moves from the peritoneum into the pleural space via small diaphragmatic defects (ie, pleural effusion).  Even small pleural effusions can cause dyspnea and hyperventilation; however, this would cause respiratory (vs metabolic) alkalosis.  The accumulation of a larger amount of fluid can impair diaphragmatic excursion and cause hypoventilation instead (ie, respiratory acidosis).

(Choice C)  Hepatorenal syndrome (ie, cirrhosis leading to acute kidney injury [AKI]) would cause metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia due to impaired renal clearance of acidic wastes and potassium.  This patient has metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia.  His elevation in blood urea nitrogen and creatinine is likely due to a reduction in circulating blood volume and subsequent mild AKI.  His mild hyponatremia on admission was possibly due to volume overload (dilutional), which has improved with diuresis (excess water diuresis compared to sodium loss).

(Choice E)  Severe sepsis typically presents with primary metabolic acidosis due to excess production of lactic acid resulting from organ and tissue ischemia.

Educational objective:
Ascites in patients with cirrhosis is caused by sodium and fluid retention and is therefore treated with loop diuretics.  Loop diuretics cause electrolyte derangements (eg, hypokalemia) and can also lead to metabolic alkalosis (elevated serum bicarbonate, pH >7.45) due to increased renal hydrogen excretion.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Metabolic alkalosis

questionList.questionText:
Patient Information
Age: 79 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department

History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: altered mental status and seizure
History of Present Illness:
• lethargic and confused for the past several days
• no other systemic symptoms
• develops a brief tonic-clonic seizure while in the emergency department
Past Medical History:
• hypertension
Medications:
• hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine started 3 weeks ago
Allergies:
• no known drug allergies
Family History:
• noncontributory
Psychosocial History:
• retired schoolteacher
• married, lives with husband

Physical Examination

TempPulseRespBPO2 SatHtWtBMI
36.8 C
(98.2 F)		84/min16/min125/70
mm Hg		99%
on RA		--18.9 kg/m2
 

• Appearance: lethargic, arousable
• HEENT: moist mucous membranes
• Neurologic: cranial nerves intact, moves all extremities equally

Diagnostic Studies
• CT scan of the head: no acute infarction, mass effect, or midline shift

Question: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Thiazide-induced hyponatremia

Pathogenesis

  • ↓ Water excretion (ADH-dependent & ADH-independent mechanisms)
  • ↑ Water intake (natural tendency to polydipsia)

Risk factors & presentation

  • Advanced age (mean age >75), female, low BMI
  • Typically within few weeks of therapy or after acute event (eg, diarrhea)
  • Patients often euvolemic with subtle symptoms (eg, confusion)

Treatment

  • Discontinue thiazide
  • Correct hyponatremia (eg, IV fluids)

ADH = antidiuretic hormone; IV = intravenous.

This patient developed a seizure while being evaluated for new-onset encephalopathy (eg, lethargy, confusion).  A common cause of seizures is increased neuronal excitability caused by electrolyte abnormalities.  This patient was recently (eg, 3 weeks ago) given hydrochlorothiazide (a thiazide diuretic), which can cause severe hyponatremia, classically in elderly female patients with a low BMI.

Affected patients likely have a combination of increased water intake (eg, natural tendency to polydipsia) and increased water retention (ie, impaired water excretion), leading to hyponatremia.

  • Some patients have thiazide-induced mild volume depletion that causes antidiuretic hormone (ADH)–mediated water retention.

  • However, most are euvolemic (eg, moist mucous membranes), likely signifying ADH-independent mechanisms.  These mechanisms may reflect either direct thiazide effects (eg, ADH-independent water retention through poorly understood mechanisms) or patient factors (eg, age-related reduced ability to dilute urine, genetic predisposition to water retention, decreased glomerular filtration rate).

Clinical findings can be subtle (eg, confusion), but seizures can occur with severe electrolyte abnormalities.   Treatment of thiazide-induced hyponatremia includes permanent thiazide discontinuation and intravenous fluid administration; hypertonic saline is typically used in severe cases (eg, seizures).

In addition to hyponatremia, thiazides may cause mild hypercalcemia that is usually not sufficient to cause encephalopathy; in addition, hypercalcemia is not associated with seizures because of decreased neuronal excitability (Choice A).

(Choices B and C)  Hypocalcemia can cause seizures, although only if it is severe; it is unlikely in this patient without predisposing conditions (eg, chronic kidney disease or hypoparathyroidism from recent neck surgery) and other symptoms (eg, carpopedal spasm, paresthesia).  Hypernatremia is also unlikely in the absence of risk factors, such as critical illness with disrupted thirst or being bedridden with advanced dementia.

(Choice D)  Hypokalemia can occur with thiazide use.  However, it is typically mild; in addition, classical manifestations of severe hypokalemia include muscle weakness and arrhythmias (vs confusion and seizures).

Educational objective:
Seizures are commonly caused by electrolyte abnormalities, most commonly severe hyponatremia.  Hyponatremia is often seen in the setting of thiazide diuretic use, classically in elderly female patients with a low BMI (ie, thiazide-induced hyponatremia).  Treatment includes permanent thiazide discontinuation and intravenous fluid administration.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hyponatremia

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Thiazide-associated hyponatremia: clinical manifestations and pathophysiology.
Acute symptomatic seizures caused by electrolyte disturbances.
Chronic hyponatremia causes neurologic and psychologic impairments.

questionList.questionText:
A 20-year-old man is found to have an elevated calcium level on pre-employment screening blood tests.  He feels well and has no polyuria, polydipsia, or constipation.  His medical history is unremarkable.  He takes no prescription medications, although he has been consuming "protein shakes and vitamin supplements" in preparation for running a marathon.  The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 82/min.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Sodium140 mEq/L
Potassium4.0 mEq/L
Chloride103 mEq/L
Bicarbonate24 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen18 mg/dL
Serum creatinine0.8 mg/dL
Calcium11.2 mg/dL
Glucose98 mg/dL
Albumin4.2 g/L
Serum parathyroid hormone level65 pg/mL (normal 10-65 pg/mL)
Urine calcium/creatinine clearance ratio<0.01

Which of the following conditions is most consistent with this patient's findings?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has mild, asymptomatic hypercalcemia and normal renal function.  In light of a high-normal parathyroid hormone (PTH) level and low urinary calcium excretion, this presentation is consistent with familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH).  FHH is a benign autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation of the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR).  Normally, high-normal calcium levels suppress PTH secretion by the parathyroid glands, but in FHH, higher calcium concentrations are required to suppress PTH release.  Concurrently, the defective CaSR leads to increased reabsorption of calcium in renal tubules.

In the evaluation of hypercalcemia, an elevated (or inappropriately normal) PTH level suggests either primary hyperparathyroidism or FHH.  However, patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have increased urinary calcium excretion due to excessive mobilization of calcium from bones, whereas patients with FHH usually have very low urinary calcium levels (typically <100 mg/24 hr).  Urine calcium excretion can be more precisely assessed using the urine calcium/creatinine clearance ratio (UCCR):

UCCR = (Caurine/Caserum)/(Creaturine/Creatserum)

UCCR is usually <0.01 in FHH compared to >0.02 in primary hyperparathyroidism (Choice C).

Most patients with FHH are asymptomatic, although potential complications include pancreatitis and chondrocalcinosis.  In the absence of complications, no specific treatment is required.

(Choices B, D, E, and F)  Patients with multiple myeloma, renal cell carcinoma, sarcoidosis, and vitamin D toxicity may also present with hypercalcemia, but PTH levels are typically suppressed due to feedback inhibition.

Educational objective:
Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia is caused by a mutation in the calcium-sensing receptor.  It is a benign disorder characterized by asymptomatic hypercalcemia, elevated or inappropriately normal parathyroid hormone levels, and low urinary calcium excretion.  It can be differentiated from primary hyperparathyroidism, which has increased urinary calcium excretion, by the urine calcium/creatinine clearance ratio.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hypercalcemia

questionList.questionText:
A 56-year-old man is evaluated for tachypnea.  The patient, a construction worker, fell off a roof while working yesterday.  He sustained an open femur fracture, which required urgent surgical repair.  Medical history includes chronic low back pain, for which he has been taking oxycodone.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 155/100 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 30/min.  Pulse oximetry reading is 99%.  On physical examination, the lungs are clear to auscultation.  Heart sounds are regular.  The abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation.  Arterial blood gas analysis while the patient is breathing room air shows the following:

pH7.53
PaO2102 mm Hg
PaCO225 mm Hg
Bicarbonate20 mEq/L

Which of the following best explains the laboratory findings in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Common causes of primary acid-base disturbance

Metabolic acidosis

Elevated anion gap

  • Poor tissue perfusion (ie, lactic acidosis)
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Kidney failure (ie, uremia)
  • Certain toxicities (eg, methanol, ethylene glycol)

Normal anion gap

  • Severe diarrhea
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Excess normal saline infusion

Metabolic alkalosis

  • Nasogastric suctioning or severe vomiting
  • Diuretic overuse
  • Primary hyperaldosteronism

Respiratory acidosis
(hypoventilation)

  • Central respiratory depression (eg, opioid overdose)
  • OHS, neuromuscular weakness
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

Respiratory alkalosis
(hyperventilation)

  • Acute V/Q mismatch (eg, PE, pneumonia)
  • Anxiety, inadequate pain control
  • High altitude, pregnancy

OHS = obesity hypoventilation syndrome; PE = pulmonary embolism; V/Q = ventilation/perfusion.

This patient has a high pH of 7.53 and a low PaCO2 of 25 mm Hg, consistent with primary respiratory alkalosis.  The mildly decreased serum bicarbonate reflects partial renal compensation (increased renal excretion of bicarbonate), which begins after 6-12 hours and takes approximately 72 hours to achieve full compensation.  Primary respiratory alkalosis is caused by excess CO2 exhalation due to hyperventilation.

Hyperventilation in this patient is accompanied by hypertension and sinus tachycardia.  In the setting of an open femur fracture that was surgically repaired the day before, these findings suggest the increase in respiratory and sympathetic drive that occurs with acute pain (ie, inadequate pain control).  Patients with long-term opioid use (eg, oxycodone for chronic back pain in this patient) may develop opioid tolerance and are at risk for significant postoperative pain.  They may require higher opioid doses or multimodal strategies (eg, regional anesthesia).

Other postoperative diagnoses that can present similarly and must be considered include pulmonary embolism, pulmonary edema, and pneumonia.  Significant pulmonary embolism is highly unlikely in the absence of any evidence of hypoxemia (Choice D).  Pulmonary edema and pneumonia typically cause hypoxemia as well and are unlikely in the presence of a normal lung examination.

(Choice A)  Excessive infusion of normal saline (NaCl) leads to hyperchloremia.  An increase in chloride ions drives bicarbonate intracellularly to maintain electronegativity, which decreases buffering capacity and causes metabolic acidosis.  Although this patient has a low bicarbonate level, a high pH is not consistent with acidosis.

(Choice C)  Excess opioid administration can cause opioid intoxication with a resultant respiratory acidosis due to hypoventilation (ie, decreased central respiratory drive).

(Choice E)  Sepsis commonly causes primary anion gap metabolic acidosis due to lactic acidosis.  Respiratory compensation would cause an increased respiratory rate and a decreased PaCO2.   However, laboratory values would be consistent with the primary disorder (metabolic acidosis) and show a low pH and low bicarbonate level.

Educational objective:
Primary respiratory alkalosis (ie, high pH, low PaCO2) is caused by hyperventilation, which is common in postoperative patients.  The combination of hyperventilation, sinus tachycardia, and hypertension in addition to normal oxygenation suggests inadequate pain control.  Patients with opioid tolerance due to long-term use are particularly at increased risk.

questionList.questionText:
A 66-year-old man comes to the office for routine follow-up.  He has had mild fatigue but otherwise feels well.  The patient has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, chronic kidney disease, and ischemic cardiomyopathy.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 82/min.  Physical examination shows moist mucous membranes.  A 2/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex is unchanged from the previous examination.  The patient has trace edema in the bilateral lower extremities.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Sodium135 mEq/L
Potassium6.0 mEq/L
Bicarbonate24 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen38 mg/dL
Creatinine2.4 mg/dL
Calcium8.2 mg/dL
Glucose196 mg/dL

Two months ago, creatinine was 2.3 mg/dL.  ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with no other abnormalities.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Medication-induced hyperkalemia

Medication

Mechanism

ACE inhibitors & ARBs

↓ Aldosterone secretion (↓ AT II production; block AT II receptor)

NSAIDs

↓ Renin secretion → ↓ aldosterone

↓ Renal perfusion → ↓ distal Na+ delivery →  ↓ ENaC activity

Potassium-sparing
diuretics

Inhibit ENaC (eg, amiloride) or aldosterone receptor (eg, spironolactone)

Heparin

↓ Aldosterone production

Trimethoprim

Inhibits ENaC (similar to amiloride)

Cyclosporine

Blocks aldosterone activity

Nonselective
β-blockers

Interfere with β2-mediated intracellular K+ uptake

Digoxin

Inhibits Na+/K+-ATPase

Succinylcholine

Causes extracellular leakage of K+ through acetylcholine receptors

ARBs = angiotensin II receptor blockers; AT = angiotensin; ENaC = epithelial sodium channel; NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

In the outpatient setting, hyperkalemia is most often caused by reduced urinary potassium excretion due to renal insufficiency or medications/disorders that impair the renin-angiotensin axis.  Less common causes include the movement of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space (eg, uncontrolled hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis) or increased tissue catabolism (eg, trauma, tumor lysis syndrome).

Hyperkalemia is usually asymptomatic until potassium rises to ≥6.5 mEq/L, but acute hyperkalemia can sometimes cause symptoms at lower levels.  Common manifestations include ascending muscle weakness with flaccid paralysis, cardiac arrhythmia (eg, heart block, bradycardia), and ECG changes (eg, peaked T waves → short QT interval → QRS widening → sine wave).

Urgent therapy (eg, calcium gluconate, insulin with glucose) is typically reserved for ECG changes, potassium ≥6.5 mEq/L, and/or rapidly rising potassium due to tissue breakdown, none of which are present in this patient (Choice A).  The next step is to exclude acute secondary causes (eg, uncontrolled hyperglycemia, tumor lysis syndrome).  A review of recent/current medications should be conducted to determine whether any trigger hyperkalemia.  Common offending agents include nonselective beta-adrenergic blockers, potassium-sparing diuretics (eg, triamterene), ACE inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor blockers, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.  This patient with chronic kidney disease and a significant cardiac history is likely on a renin-angiotensin system inhibitor, which often triggers hyperkalemia.

(Choice B)  Patients with persistent, unexplained hyperkalemia should be evaluated further for hypoaldosteronism with serum renin and aldosterone levels.  However, this patient's medications should first be reviewed.

(Choice C)  Uncontrolled hyperglycemia due to insulin deficiency can shift potassium out of cells, leading to hyperkalemia.  However, these patients tend to have significant hyperglycemia (>300 mg/dL) and, often, anion gap metabolic acidosis due to ketoacidosis.  This patient's normal bicarbonate and lack of significant hyperglycemia make this less likely.

(Choice D)  Urinalysis has limited value for evaluating hyperkalemia.  However, urine electrolytes can help differentiate renal from extrarenal causes of hyperkalemia; this might be indicated if no offending medications are found.

Educational objective:
The most common causes of hyperkalemia include renal insufficiency, medications, and disorders impairing the renin-angiotensin axis.  Common offending medications include nonselective beta-adrenergic blockers, potassium-sparing diuretics (eg, triamterene), ACE inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor blockers, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
